node.contents: steve martin. thanks for reply. My HAproxy server is able to connect both the Rabbitmq server. My goal is the connection should be managed by HAProxy. e.g if I have 2 rabbit server behind HAProxy and publish 1000 messages then 500 msg should go in rabbit1 and 500 msg should go in remain. And if I add rabbitmq server dynamically in HAProxy server HAP should distribute among all the rabbit server. Currently what I am suffering is all 1000 msg goes in rabbit1 and not in both.

astNode.text: steve martin. thanks for reply. My HAproxy server is able to connect both the Rabbitmq server. And if I add rabbitmq server dynamically in HAProxy server HAP should distribute among all the rabbit server. Currently what I am suffering is all 1000 msg goes in rabbit1 and not in both.

node.contents: When you say that it works but messages are only published on one server, surely this is an indication of it not working? From the HAProxy machine can you make an AMQP connection to BOTH servers? I note that they are on different networks, can you post a screen grab of the stats page so that we can see what HAProxy is doing. Incidentally, what is your goal here? Using HAProxy to RR messages to different servers if something that could probably be better managed through a fanout exchange.

node.contents: I want to use HAProxy as a load balancer. I want to put two rabbitmq server behind haproxy. Both the rabbitmq server are on different instance of EC2. I have configure HAProxy server by following this reference. I works but the problem is messages are not published in roundrobin pattern. Messages are publish only on one server. Is there any different configuration for my requirement?

Is there any different configuration for my requirement?

node.contents: I have made some R&D on this and found that HAProxy is round robin the connection on the rabbitmq server. for ex: if i request for 10 connections then it will round robin the 10 connection over my 2 rabbitmq servers and publish the message.

node.contents: Remove the 'backup' from the server definitions.

astNode.text: Remove the 'backup' from the server definitions.

node.contents: A backup server is one that will be used when all others are down. Specifying all your servers as backup without using option allbackups will likely have untoward consequences.

astNode.text: A backup server is one that will be used when all others are down. Specifying all your servers as backup without using option allbackups will likely have untoward consequences.

node.contents: Change the relevant portion of your config to the following:

astNode.text: Change the relevant portion of your config to the following:

elements.contents: listen rebbitmq *:5672 mode tcp balance roundrobin stats enable option forwardfor option tcpka server web2 46.XX.XX.XXX:5672 check inter 5000 server web1 176.XX.XX.XX:5672 check inter 5000

fragments.text: listen rebbitmq *:5672 mode tcp balance roundrobin stats enable option forwardfor option tcpka server web2 46.XX.XX.XXX:5672 check inter 5000 server web1 176.XX.XX.XX:5672 check inter 5000

units.rawText: listen rebbitmq *:5672 mode tcp balance roundrobin stats enable option forwardfor option tcpka server web2 46.XX.XX.XXX:5672 check inter 5000 server web1 176.XX.XX.XX:5672 check inter 5000

node.contents: Recommend you elaborate on how to configure the queues in such a fashion.

astNode.text: Recommend you elaborate on how to configure the queues in such a fashion.

node.contents: Messages get published to an exchange which will route to a queue.

astNode.text: Messages get published to an exchange which will route to a queue.

node.contents: You probably didn't configure you queues with {"x-ha-policy","all"}. Based on the fact that the exchange routing is working on both nodes this is probably all you are missing.

astNode.text: You probably didn't configure you queues with {"x-ha-policy","all"}. Based on the fact that the exchange routing is working on both nodes this is probably all you are missing.

node.contents: Note: Pre Rabbit 3.0 you would declare a queue with the x-ha-policy argument and it would be mirrored. With rabbit 3.0 you need to apply a policy (ha-mode = all). You can set policies through the api or the api tools (rabbitmqctl, management gui). i.e.

astNode.text: Note: Pre Rabbit 3.0 you would declare a queue with the x-ha-policy argument and it would be mirrored. With rabbit 3.0 you need to apply a policy (ha-mode = all). You can set policies through the api or the api tools (rabbitmqctl, management gui). i.e.

node.contents: rabbitmqctl set_policy -p '/' MirrorAllQueues '.+' '{"ha-mode": "all"}'

astNode.text: rabbitmqctl set_policy -p '/' MirrorAllQueues '.+' '{"ha-mode": "all"}'

node.contents: The AMQP protocol is designed to use persistent connections, meaning you won't get a new connection per AMQP message (to avoid the overhead of constantly reconnecting). This means that a load balancer such as HAProxy will not be effective in balancing out your messages - it can only help with balancing out your connections.

astNode.text: The AMQP protocol is designed to use persistent connections, meaning you won't get a new connection per AMQP message (to avoid the overhead of constantly reconnecting). This means that a load balancer such as HAProxy will not be effective in balancing out your messages - it can only help with balancing out your connections.

node.contents: Thus you cannot achieve your stated goal. If, however, your actual goal is to distribute messages evenly to consumers of those RabbitMQ instances, then you can use clustering as Karsten describes or you can use federation.

astNode.text: Thus you cannot achieve your stated goal. If, however, your actual goal is to distribute messages evenly to consumers of those RabbitMQ instances, then you can use clustering as Karsten describes or you can use federation.

node.contents: Federation setup:

astNode.text: Federation setup:

node.contents: First you need to enable the federation plugins:

astNode.text: First you need to enable the federation plugins:

elements.contents: rabbitmq-plugins enable rabbitmq_federation rabbitmq-plugins enable rabbitmq_federation_management

units.rawText: rabbitmq-plugins enable rabbitmq_federation rabbitmq-plugins enable rabbitmq_federation_management

node.contents: Then for each of your servers log on to the RabbitMQ Web UI as an administrator and go to Admin > "Federation Upstreams" > "Add a new upstream" and add the other server(s) as upstream(s).

astNode.text: Then for each of your servers log on to the RabbitMQ Web UI as an administrator and go to Admin > "Federation Upstreams" > "Add a new upstream" and add the other server(s) as upstream(s).

node.contents: Now you need to define a policy for each exchange/queue you want to be federated. I only managed to get federation working for queues mind you, so I would try that first. Go to Admin > "Policies" > "Add / update a policy" and add a policy that targets the queue(s) you want federated.

astNode.text: Now you need to define a policy for each exchange/queue you want to be federated. I only managed to get federation working for queues mind you, so I would try that first. Go to Admin > "Policies" > "Add / update a policy" and add a policy that targets the queue(s) you want federated.
